text:
PROFESSOR: So we're really
excited about Highlights
for High School.

We're excited to
see how it's used.

There was an email that
arrived by early this morning

from China, celebrating
this new portal,

and it's an exciting
new chapter.

We can't end the program
without a special acknowledgment

of OCW's many
financial supporters

and without whom
it simply couldn't

have been possible for
MIT to develop OCW.

And it won't be possible for
us to sustain in the future
except for their help.

Among our many individual donors
have been several MIT alumni

who take pride in
what OCW stands for,

pride in MIT's
tradition of sharing
what we have with the world.

I want to especially thank Jon
Gruber from the class of 1964

and Larry Birenbaum,
the class of 1969,

for their leadership gifts
that will help to endow OCW.

Generous support for
Highlights for High School,

I just mentioned, Charlene
and [? Dary ?] Kabcenell

and [? Barry ?] and [? Stacey ?]
[? Newman ?] and also
by the Lord Foundation.

So we want to thank
them again also.

Finally, MIT is extremely
grateful, extraordinarily

grateful for contributions
by three organizations

who really made OCW
a reality, and let
me mention each of them.

First of all, under
the leadership

of CEO, Sheryl Handler,
who graduated in 1985,

Ab Initio became a major
corporate sponsor of OCW

Ab Initio's substantial
financial support has been

crucial in enabling us to reach
our 1,800-course milestone.

I want to invite Sheryl
up to thank her personally

for her contributions,
her leadership team.
And we're-- she's going to.
I have a a gift for you, Sheryl.
SHERYL HANDLER: Oh, no.

PROFESSOR: Yes,
it's a little one.
Please.

Presenting you with
the [? gifts, ?]

but thank you so much
for helping [INAUDIBLE]

SHERYL HANDLER: And
thank you for what

you're going to be doing
with the high school
students and all those to come.
Thank you [INAUDIBLE]
[APPLAUSE]

PROFESSOR: I would say, not
that this is a surprise,

we have actually-- well,
the gifts are this, a globe,
and a--

with a plaque on it
recognizing your contribution.
So thank you, Sheryl.

In 2001, shortly
after OpenCourseWares

was publicly announced, the
William and Flora Hewlett

Foundation and the Andrew
W Mellon foundation

committed funding to support the
development and launch of OCW,

and in doing so, really became
full partners on this journey.

Clearly, OCW wouldn't
be what it is

today was it not for the
substantial contributions,

both financial and programmatic,
of these two foundations.

Both have awarded
multiple grants

that support OCW from
the initial startup phase

through the publication
of the 1,800 courses.

Both foundations have also been
generous in their wise counsel,

helping to steer us on
a course for success.

I want to specially
acknowledge the support

we've received from the
Hewlett Foundation program

director, Mike Smith, the
Hewlett Foundation program

officer, Cathy Casserly, and
Mellon Foundation program
officer, Ira Fuchs.

We're fortunate to
have Mike with us today

for the celebration, and I
would like him to also come.
Where's Mike?

Simply stated, we wouldn't
be here today celebrating

were it not for Sheryl,
Mike, their colleagues

at Hewlett, Mellon
and Ab Initio.
Thank you so much.

PROFESSOR: Mike, I thought
you had a few remarks,

if I could invite you to come
up and share them with us.

Sorry to make you
walk back and forth.
MIKE SMITH: Please.

It's getting late for
everybody, I think.

So thank you, Susan,
and thank you, Chuck.
And thank you, [? Ann. ?]
Where'd [? Ann ?] go?
She leave?

Oh, there she is
in the front row.
She should be.

We ended up working most
closely with [? Ann ?]

over the last five years,
an extraordinary time.

And a wonderful synergy
developed, I think, that--
and we hope actually--

hope it helped in
OCW and at MIT also.

So I want to thank you also
from Paul Brest, the president

of the foundation, and from
Walter Hewlett, the chairman

of the board, and
also from Cathy,
who couldn't be here today.

And she's been the
program officer for OCW

for the last three
or four years,

and hopefully she'll
be working with MIT

in lots of areas over
the next few years.

2001 has been mentioned
as a date that stands out.

I have this distinct
memory of Chuck Vest
walking into my office one day.

I don't think we'd met
before, but maybe we'd
passed at some point.

And he said something like,
have I got a deal for you.
[LAUGHTER]

For a measly $100 million,
shared with Mellon,

you can help MIT put all of its
courses on the web for free.

It turned out to be a lot
less than $100 million.

But that was the introduction,
and then we had a half an hour,

three quarters of an
hour discussion of it.

The idea immediately
sparked my interest,
and I took it to my president.
And he said yes, let's do it.
Prepare it for the board.

So in April, two months after
Chuck had walked in the door
or so, I took it to the board.
I was all prepared.

I mean, this was going
to be a big expenditure.

We're saying, your commitments
of all sorts of money
and so on.

And so I launch
into this kind of--

not impassioned, but
energetic defense of the idea.

And about two minutes lapsed,
and Walter Hewlett said, stop.
I get it.

Three years ago, I
had to figure out what
to do with my music collection.

He's got this wonderful
collection of music.

And I thought, well,
maybe I should sell it,

or I could put it up on the
web, and people could buy it.
And I said no, why not?
I don't need the money.

I'll put it up on
the web for free.

Well, that ended the
discussion in the board.

If the chairman and the
senior Hewlett there,

the senior Hewlett
representative

said he liked it, the rest
of the board liked it.
It--
[LAUGHTER]

And the support for
this idea since then

has come from Walter,
and has come from Paul,

and it's come from the
board in really major ways.

I don't think either
of us that day

could have imagined the effect
of MIT's extraordinary act.

Churchill said, "If
you have knowledge,

let others light their
candles with it."
But Churchill mashed that quote.

He mashed it from
Thomas Jefferson,

who had said, "He who
receives an idea from me

receives instruction itself
without lessening mine,

as he who lights
his taper at mine

receives light
without darkening me."
So there's one of the first--
one of the early mashes around--
or at least around this concept.

In a recent report, John and
Dan [? Atkin ?] and Al Hammond

argued that over
the past six years,

there's been a sea change in
the attitudes of educators,

from a protectionist position
with regard to education

materials to one of openness,
a response to MIT's bold move

and taking to heart Churchill's
and Jefferson's observations.

At the Hewlett Foundation,
the MIT OCW grant

stimulated a six-year program,
which we're now just ending,

focused on making open education
resources available for free

on the web for all to use,
reuse, and otherwise modify
for their purposes.

The MIT OCW grant was our first,
largest, and most important
award.

Our work spans higher
education and K to 12

in the US, Europe, Asia, Africa,
and throughout the world.

Grants include Harvard
library collections, full

cognitive tutor courses from
Carnegie Mellon, Multimedia, AP

and other high school courses,
a network of country web

sites for teachers in Europe,
reams OU UK material, WGBH

video archives, physics
simulations for high school

and college created by
a Nobel Prize winner,

teacher training materials
in sub-Saharan Africa,

and dozens of other
projects of the same sort.

MIT is the only university to
place its entire set of courses
on the web.

But through MIT's example
and our combined hard work,

there are now over
150 universities

that we know of
around the world that

are following the MIT model
of putting OpenCourseWare
on the web.

And we actually followed, to
some extent in our funding,

the strategy that was mentioned
in one of the questions.
That is, trying to pick up--

not having MIT
assure the quality

of the particular
areas, but picking

up areas like public health,
or medicine, or, in the case

of Notre Dame, studies of
divinity and ethics and so on,

areas that may not
have been covered fully
by MIT's broad span of courses.

And there are lots of
other areas like that.

Department of ed--
there's no [INAUDIBLE]

there's no school of
education that has yet put
its materials up on the web.

You can go down
through a whole series
of different areas like that.

And we tried to do a
little bit of that,

but we've actually now
moved in a different way,

because taking to heart what
John and Dan and Al Hammond

said, we've now begun to
change our set of strategies.

We're going to move from funding
exemplary bodies of content,

like MIT, or like the
Harvard libraries,

or whatever, to focus
on two strategies.

One of them is the
infrastructure issues
that Chuck mentioned.

That is, what are the barriers
to getting open education

resources up there in
a really serious way?
There's the IP issues.

There's-- you
mentioned, I believe,
the infrastructure issue.

So a number of different
issues of this sort that

need attention and
need continuing

attention by a foundation or
by some other set of funders,

just in order to
keep the pot boiling.

But in the meantime, there are
all sorts of things going up

on the web, and so we don't--
we're not worried particularly

about the expanse of the web,
or the wealth of the content,
or anything else.

What we're worried
about is keeping

the sets of networks
that are beginning
to form alive and thriving.

And if we can do that, we can
have this whole area really
be alive and thriving itself.

The second area that
we're focusing on

is to think about how openness,
open content materials,

open tools, open objects,
can be used to enhance
teaching and learning.

And we want to, over
the next five years--

and the board has
approved this proposal--

spend roughly $20 million a
year on both the infrastructure

and on this, probably
split half and half,

taking sets of ideas about
how to really improve

the quality of learning,
using openness as a criterion.

So why does openness
work in this way?

All these issues have
been raised here,

but one aspect of
openness, of course,

is that it's free to
everybody in the world.
This is quite an amazing aspect.

A second aspect of
openness is that it

has unlocked content
which has, in the past,

been behind a closed
door of sorts.

MIT's OpenCourseWare
is an example of that.

Harvard's library is
another example and so on.
So those are two examples of it.

But there are other
aspects of openness,

and that is the use
and reuse, which

allow people to take and modify
for themselves, to translate,

to do what Dick is talking
about throughout the world,

where he's talking about
indigenous people creating
content.

But they'll be able to
pull down, use, mix,

mash the content that exists
from the developed world,

from MIT, from lots of
other places in order

to create it for
their own people,
for their particular purposes.
Two parts to this.

One is that that's an
extraordinary thing,

because it allows you to modify,
and personalize, and alter

those materials so they
can be better used.

But the other part of it
is that the simple act

of taking that
material and changing

it is an act of creation,
is an act of learning.

How are we going to
take this material

and really change it in such a
way that it makes sense to us?

That's the set of skills
and understandings

and so on that we probably
don't have yet in many places,

but that will be-- will grow
and be very active over time.

So just to end, I almost
feel as though I'm repeating
what everybody else has said.

If we didn't know what
was going to happen,

if Chuck and I didn't know
what was going to happen in six
years, we certainly don't--

from then, we
certainly don't know

what's going to happen
six years from now.
I don't think any of us do.

Changes are really quite
extraordinary in technology,

in this growing
youth understanding

of how to manipulate and
change and modify and so

on that we talked about in
the session a few minutes ago.

My grandchildren--
my children are

too old to be fully
in this generation.
My grandchildren are.

They're doing all the things
that everybody mentioned here.

And they're teaching,
actually, one
of my sons, who is a techie.

And when he comes and
visits his nephew,

his nephew is in there working
away, showing him something

that he hasn't seen
before, which is a--

it's a wonderful
cross-generational aspect.

Chuck has one vision, which
is worth anybody looking

at if they haven't looked at
it, that vision of the meta
university.

And interestingly,
in the last week,

we've heard from two
different parties

that they're trying to figure
out how to implement the meta
university.

So-- and you probably
don't even know about it.

There's a group in Australia,
and there's a group in Canada
that are thinking about this.

So the world is
changing underneath us.

It's changing very
fast underneath us.

Just another example of
that is that, I believe

three years ago, Dick Roe
had probably never heard

of OpenCourseWare,
or if he had, he
wasn't quite sure what it was.

He is now very actively,
very deep into these things.

And so I wish everybody well,
and I want to thank you again.

It's been a great ride
for the last six years,

and I'm sure it'll be a great
ride for the next six years.
Thank you.

PROFESSOR: So I have a couple
of brief administrative things.

I know there are members of
the press in the audience.

Those of you who wish to stay
and meet with one of our--

in the press room to
get a further briefing

on Highlights for High
School or other aspects

of OpenCourseWare,
if you'll just

come down to that sign over
there when we conclude,

Steve Carson of the
OpenCourseWare staff

will lead you to the media
room, and you can ask questions
and have further discussion.

The second thing is to thank
all of you for coming here.

It is greatly
appreciated and trying
to convey the excitement.
And the last is-- before we go--

is there will be a
reception outside after,

immediately following the
closing of these ceremonies.

So let me end with the following
more personalized note.

I've spent all my,
what wife claims is

a very late adolescence, and
all my adult life here at MIT.

And I'm acutely aware this
is a sea of excellence where

great ideas formed by
great people happen.

And yet, even
within that baseline

of extraordinary
excellence, a few things

over the course of a
decade or two decades

emerge from an
institution like MIT
to have extraordinary impact.

And I'm willing to wager
that OpenCourseWare, when
the history of the early part--

MIT's history is
written and we think

about the early part of this
21st century and ask, what

are the extraordinary things
MIT did in that period--

in the same way when we look at
the 1940s about the development

of radar and the development
of artificial intelligence

and a few other signature
events in MIT's history,

in that same way, it's my
view that OpenCourseWare

will be on that very
short list of things

that, even in an illustrious
history of an institution,
stand out.

And so I'm going to try
to remember this moment,

remember this event I'd
like to thank you for all--

for coming, and please
join us for reception.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
